concepts.name: Circadian Rhythms
concepts.description: Biological processes regulating 24-hour physiological cycles, including sleep-wake patterns. Central to the study's investigation of time-of-day effects on cognitive performance in evening chronotypes.

concepts.name: Evening Chronotype
concepts.description: A circadian preference for later sleep and wake times, defining the study's participant group (late sleepers). Critical for understanding why morning exercise interventions were tested.

concepts.name: Morning Cognitive Decline
concepts.description: Reduced cognitive performance (e.g., reaction time) observed in the early morning hours. The core phenomenon the study addresses through exercise intervention.

concepts.name: Medium-Intensity Exercise
concepts.description: Exercise at 40-60% of maximum heart rate, shown to correlate with improved post-exercise cognitive performance. The key intervention variable with practical implications.

concepts.name: Psychomotor Vigilance Task (PVT)
concepts.description: Standard cognitive test measuring sustained attention and reaction time via response to visual stimuli. Used to quantify morning cognitive decline in the study.

concepts.name: Visual Stroop Task
concepts.description: Cognitive test assessing executive function and attentional control through color-word interference. Primary measure for exercise-cognition interaction analysis.

concepts.name: Weekend Sleep Duration
concepts.description: Total sleep time on non-training days, correlated with pre-exercise PVT performance. Highlights sleep's role in baseline cognitive function for evening chronotypes.

concepts.name: Circadian Phase
concepts.description: Timing of an individual's internal biological clock relative to external cues. Negatively correlated with post-exercise Stroop performance, indicating phase alignment importance.

concepts.name: Chronotype-Specific Intervention
concepts.description: Tailoring exercise timing to individual circadian preferences. The study's novel approach to optimizing cognitive outcomes in evening-oriented populations.

methods.name: Cross-Sectional Study
methods.description: Observational design collecting data at a single time point. Used to assess associations between chronotype, exercise, and cognitive performance without longitudinal manipulation.

methods.name: Actigraphy
methods.description: Objective sleep/wake monitoring using wrist-worn accelerometers. Applied to quantify sleep patterns and validate self-reported sleep data in participants.

methods.name: Self-Report Questionnaires
methods.description: Standardized surveys assessing sleep habits and exercise routines. Complemented actigraphy data to capture subjective sleep quality and training patterns.

methods.name: Psychomotor Vigilance Task
methods.description: Standardized cognitive assessment requiring rapid button presses to visual stimuli. Administered pre- and post-exercise to measure attentional decline and intervention effects.

methods.name: Visual Stroop Task
methods.description: Cognitive test measuring interference resolution via color-naming of incongruent words. Used to evaluate executive function changes after exercise interventions.

methods.name: Correlation Analysis
methods.description: Statistical method quantifying relationships between variables (e.g., exercise duration vs. Stroop performance). Applied to identify significant associations in the dataset.
